definition.value: These animals lack a vertebral column and many of which are used as model organisms in HTS screening including Drosophila, C.elegans, sea urchin, etc.
This describes the physical format such as plate density in which an assay is performed, which is generally a microplate format, but can also be an array format.
This microplate contains 96 wells. It is suitable for a low throughput assay.
The immobilization of  thousands of small molecules, genes or proteins on a glass slide for performing binding studies.
This microplate contains 384 wells. It is suitable for a HTS assay.

This microplate contains 1536 wells. It is highly miniaturized to accommodate more wells on one plate which reduces the plate handling time and allows working with very small volumes (few microliters) that reduces the cost of an assay.
It is a PubChem-specific assay stage. A summary assay references and summarizes the assays in PubChem that correspond to a screening campaign or a probe development project.
This includes vertebrate model organisms such as the Danio rerio (zebrafish), Xenopus laevis, etc which are tested generally to understand development.

It is the trend of measured readout signal, whether it increases or decreases in perturbagen treated wells, as compared to the untreated or carrier-treated wells and the endpoint mode of action of an assay.

This includes the different pieces of information about a PubChem bioassay that is available at the PubChem website, namely, the assay title, assay protocol, assay description, assay provider, endpoint name, etc.

The name of a bioassay which is associated with each assay ID (AID). It contains information about the target tested, the stage of the assay (primary or confirmatory), the assay format (biochemical or cell based), etc.

This contains the background information and rationale for performing a bioassay and is found on the PubChem website associated with each assay ID (AID). It also includes the assay design and some information on the related bioassays.

This includes the methodology used to perform a particular bioassay and is found on the PubChem website associated with each assay ID (AID). It includes the assay components and the order in which they were added, the incubation times, detection method and the kit used, etc.

use cito:

citesForInformation or citeAsSourceData some DOI or PMID
The role of an organization or individual to add an assay to a repository, such as PubChem.
This is the PubChem assay remark that can be assigned by depositors to a bioassay.

It describes the assay dynamic range considering range and data variation:
Z'=1-{3x[StdDev(poscontrol)+StdDev(negcontrol)]/[Avg(poscontrol)-Avg(negcontrol)]}

Difference of signal between positive and negative controls; assay dynamic range:
SW={Avg(poscontrol)-Avg(negcontrol)-3x[StdDev(poscontrol)+StdDev(negcontrol)]}/StdDev(poscontrol).

Measure of signal strength.
S/N=[Avg(poscontrol)-Avg(negcontrol)]/[StdDev(poscontrol)+StdDev(negcontrol)]

Measure of the signal dispersion:
CV=100x[StdDev(sample)/Avg(sample)]

Assay measurements throughput quality describes the quality of the measurements performed on each sample, such as single concentration, single repetition, concentration-response, multiple repetitions, etc.
Regular high-throughput screening (primary screening) to identify hits.
This is a typical HTS assay, which uses a plate reader and generates one or two readouts, in contrast to high content screening, which can generate tens to hundreds of parameters.
Concentration-response (dose-response) screen in which each concentration is only measured once.  This is equivalent to quantitative high-throughput screening (qHTS).
Multiple measurements (typically three) are preformed at a single concentration. This is often used as a mode of confirmatory screening following a primary screen.

Assays performed in the lead optimization stage. They are typically concentration-response high quality assays. They can involve a number of different assays depending on the required profile of the desired lead compound.
esiRNAs are endoribonuclease-prepared siRNA pools comprised of a heterogeneous mixture of siRNAs that all target the same mRNA sequence.

This refers to the infection of cells with a modified virus, which introduces viral genome containing the foreign genes. Several types of viruses are utilized for recombinant gene expression, including lentivirus, retrovirus, adenovirus, etc, with each having their own advantages and disadvantages.

This refers to the infection of cells with a disease-causing virus, which could effect humans, animals and plants. Pathogenic viruses include the influenza virus, measles virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, etc.
It is a live cell assay in which eukaryotic cells are infected with bacteria.

A brief description of the recombinant DNA created by the insertion of a gene or siRNA encoding DNA of interest into a vector. It includes information on the type of vector, the type of promoter, the selectable markers, etc., which are all considered when sub-cloning a gene of interest. The construct is transfected into cells by various methods.
The organism related to the target / meta-target of the bioassay. It includes both bacterium and eukaryote.

Most of the fungi are multicellular, e.g. molds, mushrooms, etc. They are made up of multicellular filaments known as hyphae. Several parasitic fungi exist, which infect animals and plants, e.g., Aspergillus flavus, Claviceps purpurea, Pneumocystis jirovecii, etc.
The role of an individual or a company as a creator of an assay kit, compound library, or detection instrument.

This describes the throughput and information content generated. Categorizing multiplexed (i.e. mutiple targets measured simultaneously) and multiparametric assays and high content (image-based) and regular (plate reader) assays.

Typically uses a plate reader and generates one or two readouts, in contrast to high content screening or multiplexed assays, which can generate tens to hundreds of parameters. The readout is typically from a single target / meta-target in each well.

It is a HTS assay, where the readout is measured from multiple targets from one well. E.g., several protein targets are detected simultaneously by using probes labeled with different fluorescent properties.

A physical quality which is equal to the distance between repeating units of a wave pattern (from PATO).
For fluorescence measurements, it is the wavelength at which the fluorophore is excited and the wavelength at which it emits fluorescence. In the case of absorbance, it is the wavelength at which light is absorbed by a biological entity or a dye.
For fluorescence measurements, it is the wavelength at which a fluorophore is excited
For fluorescence measurements, it is the wavelength at which an excited fluorophore emits fluorescence.
In absorbance measurements, it is the wavelength at which light is absorbed by a biological entity or a dye
The protein is only partially purified

Cells are counted to determine their viability. Cultured animal cells are counted either manually using hemocytometer, or by an automated cell counter, e.g. Coulter counter or Vi-CELL. The latter can distinguish live and dead cells by the trypan blue cell exclusion method. 
Yeast and bacterial cell growth is determined by measuring absorbance in a spectrophotometer, or by viable plate count.
This describes whether the perturbagens are tested individually or as mixtures / pools
The perturbagens are tested individually in an assay
Mixtures / pools of perturbagens are tested in an assay
This microplate contains 24 wells. It is suitable for a low throughput assay.
Vials are small containers that are used in biological measurements, including scintillation counting.
Cuvettes are used to measure absorbance or fluorescence in a spectrophotometer or fluorimeter, respectively using either plastic, glass or quartz cuvettes.
